tp:flag.tp:docstring: The CM provides the number of unread e-mails (or e-mail threads) in the main folder of your e-mail account set as UnreadMailCount property. The connection manager will update this value by emitting the UnreadMailsChanged signal.

The CM provides a detailed list of unread e-mails set as UnreadMails property. This flag implies that Supports_Unread_Mail_Count is set and cannot be combine with flag Emits_Mails_Received. The CM will update the list by emitting the UnreadMailsChanged signals.
The CM emits MailsReceived signal which provide details about newly arrived e-mails but does not maintain their read/unread status afterward. This flag cannot be combined with Supports_Unread_Mails.

The CM provides a URL (with optional POST data) that leads to the the inbox folder of the e-mail account inside a web base client. This URL can be obtained via the RequestInboxURL method. It is strongly advised to set this flag if Supports_Unread_Mail_Count is set.

The CM provides a URL (with optional POST data) that leads to the a specific mail inside a web base client. This URL can be obtained via the RequestMailURL method. It is strongly advised to set this flag if Supports_Unread_Mails or Emits_Mails_Received is set.
If possible client should fallback to RequestInboxURL if Supports_Request_Mail_URL is not set.

The CM provides an URL (with optional POST data) that leads to a e-mail editor inside a web base client. This URL can be obtained via the RequestComposeURL method. This flag is optional and does not depend on any other flags.

tp:docstring.p: Flags representing capabilities provided by a connection manager. Those values can be used as bitfield. Some flags depends or conflicts with each others. Those relations implies four different groups of protocols. While it's not mandatory, it is strongly advised that Supports_Request_Inbox_URL flag is supported to ensure that there always exists a way to open unread messages.

1) Supports_Unread_Mail_Count only This flag is generally combined with other flags but still make sense alone. This is supported by most protocols including MSN, Yahoo and Google Talk. It allows a UI to display messages like 'GMail: 4 unread messages'.

2) Emist_Mails_Received only This is the lowest level of mail notification support. It does not allow tracking information about the mail account. No supported protocol has this limited set of feature, but it is usefull while integrating external IM library with limited support of abstracted protocols (like libpurple where unread mail count is broken).
3) Supports_Unread_Mail_Count and Supports_Unread_Mails This allow full state recovery of unread mail status. It is provided by Google XMPP Mail Notification Extension.
4) Supports_Unread_Mail_Count and Emits_Mails_Received This is the most common level of support, it is provided by protocols like MSN and Yahoo.

tp:enumvalue.tp:docstring: Use GET method when opening the URL.
Use POST method when opening the URL. Refer to HTTP_Post_Data for more details.

tp:struct.name: HTTP_Post_Data
tp:struct.tp:docstring:
A pair (key, value) representing POST data compatible with application/x-www-form-urlencoded type. The strings must be valid UTF-8 strings. The character set for the key must follow the rules defined in
W3 specification for CDATA. The value should not be encoded with HTML entity.
This data may be used to generate a HTML file that will automatically load the URL with appropriate POST data (in which case the client must convert the reserved characters into HTML entities) or may use it as-is inside an UTF-8 API that will instruct the browser how to load the URL (like the Netscape Plug-in API). For this reason, the choice of non encoded UTF-8 strings is prefered.

tp:struct.name: Mail_Address
tp:struct.tp:docstring: A pair (name, address) representing an e-mail address.

tp:enumvalue.tp:docstring: The e-mail is represented as a single message send by only one sender.
The e-mail refer to a thread where multiple person may have replied.

tp:struct.name: Mail_URL
tp:struct.tp:docstring: Structure that contains required information to open Web base e-mail UI without need for re-authentication.

tp:member.name: URL
tp:member.tp:docstring: URL of the inbox folder or mail Web viewer.

tp:member.name: Post_Data
tp:member.tp:docstring: Array of name-value pair structs of the POST data to use when opening the URL. Because of the nature of the POST data, this information may not be shared between clients.

tp:simple-type.name: Mail
tp:simple-type.tp:docstring:
E-mail representation has been reduced to hash table with possible keys (of type strings) listed above. All keys are optional except the "id" key that must be provided by every protocol that supports unread mail listing. Without this key, it would not be impossible to unlist the e-mails that are no longer marked as unread.
The hash map will allow extending the protocol without any ABI changes. Only the documentation will need to be updated.
Keys
id — s
A unique ID for this e-mail
type — u (Mail_Type)
Type of e-mail. This can be set to "single", which means e-mails are represented separately, or "thread", when information is described by the protocol as thread. Note that threads may have multiple unread senders.
url-data — s
An opaque string used to build URL when calling RequestMailURL.
senders — a(ss) (Mail_Address)
An array of sender display name and e-mail address pair. Note that only e-mails thread may have multiple senders.
to-addresses — a(ss) (Mail_Address)
An array of display name and e-mail address pair of the recipients.
cc-addresses — a(ss) (Mail_Address)
An array of display name and e-mail address pair of the carbon copy recipients.
subject — s
The subject of the message.
sent-timestamp — u
A UNIX timestamp of when the message has been sent (in seconds) (optional).
received-timestamp — u
A UNIX timestamp of when the message has been received (in seconds).
has-attachments — b
A boolean of whether this message has attachments.
content-type — s
MIME type of the message contents. Plain text should be assumed if unset.
snippet — s
A small part of the message body (content-type should be set if this message is HTML encoded).
body — s
The body of the message (content-type should be set if this message is HTML encoded).
folder — s
The name of the folder containing this e-mails. If unset, inbox will be assumed.

property.name: Capabilities
property.tp:docstring:
Integer representing the bitwise-OR of supported features for e-mails notification on this server. This property cannot change after the Connection becomes CONNECTED.
This property explicitly state the behavior and availability of the other properties and signals within this interface. A connection manager that cannot at least set one of the flag in the Mail_Notification_Flags should not provide this interface.

property.name: UnreadMailCount
property.tp:docstring: The number of unread messages in the Inbox. Change notification is via UnreadMailsChanged. This property can be used if Supports_Unread_Mail_Count flag is set in Capabilities.

property.name: UnreadMails
property.tp:docstring: A array of unread Mails. Change notification is via UnreadMailsChanged. This property can be used if Supports_Unread_Mails flag is set in Capabilities.

signal.name: MailsReceived

arg.name: Mails
arg.tp:docstring: An array of Mails. Those e-mails do not have a unique "ID".

signal.tp:docstring: Emitted when new e-mails messages arrive to the inbox associated with this connection. This signal is used for protocol that are not able to maintained UnreadMails list but receives real-time notification about newly arrived e-mails. It MAY be emited only if Emits_Mails_Received flag is set in Capabilities.

signal.name: UnreadMailsChanged

arg.name: Count
arg.tp:docstring: Number of unread messages in the inbox (the new value of UnreadMailCount).

arg.name: Mails_Added
arg.tp:docstring:
A list of Mail that are being added or updated in UnreadMails. This list will be empty if the protocol does not support listing unread e-mails or threads.
Mails may be updated when the URL information (url and POST Data) have changed, or senders were added or removed from an e-mails thread (see Mail_Type).

arg.name: Mails_Removed
arg.tp:docstring: A list of e-mails ID that are being removed from UnreadMails. This list will be empty if the protocol does not support listing unread e-mails or threads.

signal.tp:docstring: Emitted when UnreadMails or UnreadMailCount have changed. It MAY be emited only if Supports_Unread_Mail_Count flag is set in Capabilities. mails_added and mails_removed may not be empty list if Supports_Unread_Mails flag is set.

tp:docstring.p: This method subscribes a client to the notification interface. This must be called by clients before using this interface.

The CM tracks a subscription count (like a refcount) for each unique bus name that has called Subscribe(). When a client calls Unsubscribe(), it releases one "reference". If a client exits (or crash), it releases all of its "references".
tp:docstring.tp:rationale: The reference count imposed on the subscription should simplify implementation of connection manager with plug-ins. Two plug-ins interested in mail notification may call Subscribe independently without relying on the CM to handle this particular action.

This method exists to initiate real time messages in the case at least one client is subscribed. This may also be used to reduce memory and network overhead when there is no active subscription. An example of protocol that benifits from this method is the Google XMPP Mail Notification extension. In this protocol, the CM receives a notification telling that something has changed. To get more information, the CM must request this information. Knowing that nobody is currently interested in this information, the CM can avoid generating useless network traffic. In the same situation, the CM may free the list of unread messages and reduce memory overhead.

method.name: Unsubscribe
method.tp:docstring:
This method unsubscribes a client from the notification interface. This should be called when a client no longer need the mail notification interface.
When the last client unsubscribe from this interface, the CM may free any uneeded data and reduce network traffic. See Unsubscribe for more rationale on this topic.

method.name: RequestInboxURL

arg.name: URL
arg.tp:docstring: A struture that contains URL and any additional data to open Web mail client without re-authentication.

method.tp:docstring:
This method creates and returns an URL and an optionnal POST data that allow openning the Inbox folder of your Web mail account. This URL may contains token with short lifetime. Thus, a client should not reuse it and request a new URL whenever it is needed. This method is implemented only if Supports_Request_Inbox_URL flag is set in Capabilities.
We are not using properties here because the tokens may not be shared between clients and that network may be required to obtain the information that leads to authentication free Web access.

method.name: RequestMailURL

arg.name: ID
arg.tp:docstring: The mail ID as found in Mail structure.

arg.name: URL_Data
arg.tp:docstring: An opaque string that contains information required by CM to build a correct URL for opening Web mail client without re-authentication. This token is part of Mail structure.

arg.name: URL
arg.tp:docstring: A struture that contains URL and any additional data to open Web mail client without re-authentication.

method.tp:docstring: This method creates and return a URL and optionnal POST data that allow openning specific mail of your Web mail account. Refer to RequestInboxURL for rationale. This method is implemented only if Supports_Request_Mail_URL flag is set in Capabilities.

method.name: RequestComposeURL

arg.name: URL
arg.tp:docstring: A struture that contains URL and any additional data to open Web mail client without re-authentication.

method.tp:docstring:
This method assembles and returns an URL and optional POST data that allow openning the mail compositer page of your Web mail account. This method is implemented only if Supports_Request_Compose_URL flag is set in Capabilities.
The goal is to allow a Web mail user to have the same level of integration as if he were using a native mail client.

tp:docstring.p: An interface to support receiving notifications about a e-mail account associated with this connection. It is intended that the connection manager has the means to provide necessary information (URL, method, POST data) so that the client is able to open the user's inbox and possibly individual messages without having to re-authenticate. To use this interface, a client must first subscribe using the Subscribe method.

When unread e-mails arrive into the into or unread e-mails are marked read or deleted the UnreadMailsChanged signal will be emitted with the new value of UnreadMailCount, an array of new or modified mails and the list of removed e-mail unique IDs. To open the web base mail client for the inbox folder or a specific mail client must call RequestInboxURL or RequestMailURL. Those methods will do proper actions to retreive the information and provide authentication free URL to the requested Web client interface.

Some protocol may not be able to provide a list of unread e-mails but may provide some information about the messages received. On such protocols, the MailsReceived signal will also be emitted, with information about the e-mails. The protocol does not keep track of any of this information.
